job_title: Head of HR in Finsbury Park, England
pros: Inspirational, values led and caring CEO with a strong vision for the furture - a great leader. Highly capable and effective Board of Trustees Strong focus on Diversity and Inclusion as well as employee welbeing It is highly rewarding working at Freedom from Toture as it strives to become the Centre of Excellence in providing much needed outstanding therapuetic and legal support to torture survivors as well as holding the UK government (and others) to account for their policies and practices which violate the human rights of their people.
cons: There is no getting away from it - the work is challenging; but this is what makes it so rewarding. Knowing that, collectively, your and your colleagues efforts are delivering such important work is highly motivational.

review_title: Freedom from Torture is a magical organisation
job_title: Head of Estates and Facilities in London, England
pros:
I walked through the main doors 4 years and 6 months ago, as an individual to start my role as The Head of Estates and Facilities. On Thursday 17th February 22, I walked out of the same doors to start my retirement, but this time as a full family member of Freedom from Torture.

Freedom from Torture is an organisation where you can't help but be touched by the compassion, caring and passionate staff who work there.

The exceptional work that is carried out by the clinicians at Freedom from Torture provides real hope for our clients.

The Covid19 pandemic brought the entire organisation together as one, with the sole aim to continue providing a much needed service for our clients who we are all here to serve. If i had to recommend one Charity above all others to work for, Freedom from Torture would be my number one choice. I have been privileged, honoured and lucky to have worked for such a passionate, 
 compassionate and caring organisation.

Thank you to my team, colleagues, friends and Freedom from Torture Family.

review_title: Great organisation, but many internal issues
pros: The important work FFT does, and the majority of its staff are incredible, and it has been an honour to work alongside this highly skilled and passionate team. It’s great to see the organisation becoming increasingly survivor led.
cons:
I have witnessed and experienced, intimidation and gas lighting often being used, particularly in recent years. Management can be hostile, aggressive and dismissive in their approach at times. Many talented staff are undervalued and experience undermined, there is overwhelmingly a lack of support from management.
Workload is often unacceptable, when this is raised this as too much pressure by staff they have been reminded that they are disposable. It is almost impossible to take TOIL. COL increases and wages in general have been frozen for quite some time. Wellbeing activities offered are no more than a tick box exercise. There is a lack of opportunities for personal or career development.

review_title: Does great work with torture survivors but no longer so great to work for.
job_title: Prefer Not To Say in London, England
pros: A lot of the staff are really great, dedicated people. The charity really helps victims of torture.
cons:
Work atmosphere has become somewhat toxic due to behaviours and actions of senior management team. SMT talk the talk about valuing staff but their actions and how they communicate with staff tell another story.

If you speak to colleagues, very few are happy and many are leaving or actively looking for new jobs. No longer a great place to work for many.

review_title: Great to work at Freedom from Torture
pros:
Provides lots of great support for Survivors of Torture, 
Friendly staff and volunteers - all who are working towards providing best experience for our clients.
Well lead by Senior Management Team 
Recognises importance of staff wellbeing - particularly for the front line roles
cons: I have been working here for 18 months and cannot think of any cons.
Not enough funding meaning work can't be done

review_title: Rewarding work in a high stress environment
pros:
- Well respected charity with a brilliant mission
- Wonderful, passionate colleagues across all departments; friendly atmosphere
- Opportunity to build your knowledge about human rights issues in many countries
- Clinical work is of high quality; clients receive excellent care from clinicians who care deeply about their clients and value professional ethics
cons:
- Staff, especially clinicians, are overworked with high caseloads. This is especially the case in the charity's regional centres located outside of London. 
- Unapproachable, unsupportive HR and senior management
- High burnout rate for clinical staff, and high turnover in other depts: in my 3 years at the charity there were 3 fundraising directors
- Notably high number of staff leave at very short notice
- Fundraising teams are often expected to meet unrealistically high targets handed down by senior management

review_title: Amazing cause and teams, some way to go on well being ok:
job_title: Fundraising & Communications Department in London, England
pros:
Amazing organisation delivering the most amazing work. 

Really great, passionate staff who are totally committed.
cons: It can feel quite chaotic, lots of staff turnover especially outside of front line staff.  Many projects appear to come out of nowhere and are expected to slot into an already tight workload. Opportunities for training and progression are limited.

pros: Employees are driven and committed. Professional people go the extra mile to provide service to clients and to support each other.
